not only help boost your application's performance with potentially minimal architectural changes needed to your application by using the edge but that

because a lot of Technology can sometimes make bold claims about what it's able to achieve while not so

edge in your own applications but to begin with we first have to answer the question what is the edge and it's unfortunately a little bit
of an overloaded term today some folks when they hear that I'm speaking about the edge they think that I'm referring
to the network Edge which is where Enterprise networks connect to third party services and this is a term that's
been around since about the 80s and while that's still a valid use of the term The Edge today that's not
usually what we're talking about when we're talking about the edge in its modern context instead what we're referring to
is a location where application code is run and where data is hosted physically
much closer to users than it has been previously now a lot of excitement about
the edge these days tends to be in a cloud computing context so that's what I'm going to focus a little bit more on today and to begin with I'm going to
take a quick step back and do a quick refresher of how major Cloud providers like Google Amazon and uh Microsoft
organize their data centers so we can see where the edge fits into things and how it's able to deliver the performance
gains that it does now on the broadest possible scale data centers are organized by region so
Us East one US West one Canada Central Asia Pacific these are all regions and within each region there are multiple
availability zones or azs and these in turn contain one or more data centers and when we're talking about
origin servers with respect to our applications we're typically talking about one of these data centers in an a
now I'm going to use AWS as my example today and looking at this next image here these are all of the uh azs in aw
Network which are represented by these yellowish orangish circles that you see and we can take a pretty educated guess
at which users are getting the best performance of our applications and it'll be whichever users live or work
closest to whichever of these circles your application code and your data is hosted in strictly because of the
reduced request latency that's incurred now the edge in a cloud computing context refers to data centers
that live outside of this network there's a lot more of them in the world and when you use the edge it's not just
one data center like with an a unless you're doing a multi- deploy situation the entire network is at your disposal
so taking a look at this next slide here you can see just how many more of them there are in the world and because the
whole network is available to you they're located to a lot more people located closer to a lot more people so
to explain what you're seeing here those blue dots represent individual Edge locations the purple ones represent
multiple ones and those bigger yellowish orangish circles are Regional Edge caches
which allows you to store a bit more data closer to your users before you maybe have to make a request to an A so
if you can handle a user's request um or even part of it through the edge Network you're going to start seeing performance
benefits because of the reduced request latency and the regions that stand the most to gain from us leveraging the edge
are South America Africa and Australia because as you can see here they each have multiple Edge locations and in the
case of Australia and South America they each have a regional Edge cach each but you can see in our previous slide they
only have one AZ and if you have legal or business requirements that require you to host
your users data in the same region in which they reside in and you're let's say a user in Northern Africa or even
Western Australia the distance that those requests have to travel is very large that is the the entire
region but if you have the edge in the case of the North African us user you
have that edge location that's right there on the East um and so that that request latency is cut in half and then
if you're that Western Australian User it's right there and so that request
will be handled in a blink of an eye compared to what you're dealing with if you were just using an a rather than not
using the edge at all so now that we've got all that context let's see a let's take a look at where the edge fits into
the request life cycle so for this example let's say we just have our origin server in US East
one or maybe Canada Central and the user in this example could be someone interacting with your services through a
website let's say like on a laptop or desktop computer it could be someone interacting with your services through a

just goes to the origin server and comes back with all the request latency that that entails now the edge which is
represented by this red diamond here when it's leveraged in your application The Edge location close cl to your user
will be the first spot that picks up and starts handling that request now best case scenario The Edge
location is able to handle the request in its entirety and sends a response back to the user but let's say that it can't for whatever reason maybe you
deployed a new version of your website maybe this is a request that's not made very often so you have nothing cashed or
maybe it's just too computationally expensive for the edge location to handle normally what will happen then is
The Edge location will make the request to the origin server get the response back and and then let's say it is the
the homepage example obviously other users users will want that exact same thing and so if at all possible you want
to cach that response so that going forward you don't need to make that additional request to the origin server
uh for other for other users and then once that's done the response just goes back to the user so pretty
straightforward it's a simple man-in-the-middle architecture but now that we can see where the edge fits into this let's look at something a little
bit more practical and a little more interesting and look at updating an existing web application to start using

so we're going to focus a little bit more on the middle wear today so let's take a look at what that code looks like

mention the performance hit of if this data center is far away from the user making the request so in my search for easy

change this homepage to a cash static asset that I put on the CDN at Bill time but we still have this Dynamic content
we need to add in somehow in that banner and that's where the edge can help us so what we're going to do is we're going to

the same the Geo object is coming off the request country is coming off the Geo object the line after that coner uh
coner request equals new middleware request we're going to put a pin in that for just one moment that's going to come into play very shortly but the line
after that coner response equals a wait request excuse me request. next what's
happening there is that is making a request to the origin but in this case it's not an a data center
it is the cached static homepage that we would have put on the CDN at Bill time so when we do have to make a request for
it it's a cashed asset it'll be faster to to retrieve Now to celebrate me being here
at goto Chicago today I want to give my fellow Canadians 50% off their orders so
assuming that the user is based in Canada I update the message to be you know hello here's your promo code and
then the two lines after that response. replace text and response. set page prop those are methods that I'm getting
through that new middleware request I mentioned a moment ago that first method replace text is updating the HTML
document and specifically the Banner element to contain the message that I want it to contain and then the line
after that set page prop is updating the nextjs page prop before the response gets sent back to the
user so to recap on what we've just done here we've gone from having a request
that is made very often that was being run every single time on an origin server potentially far away from the
user to having a cach static homepage that is faster to retrieve we have
middleware code that's running on the edge which means the request starts getting handled sooner and then even though I'm not doing it in this code
right now you can cach this response so that users that make uh make this request or other users I should say that
make this request for the homepage will get even faster responses going forward so it's all these little things but they
all add up to a really meaningful difference in terms of boosting the overall per performance of our requests
and it only took a few lines of code to to change as well as moving excuse me moving where the uh the function was
running now let's say that the edge function isn't uh middleware that's injecting content but something else
that's other that's also enriching the request object and it might be doing something more complicated where it's
making requests to databases to let's say enrich a user object in that
situation the default behavior of the edge location closest to the user handling the request can actually result
in higher latencies than if you weren't using the edge but fortunately this is
such a well-known problem that there are software providers that have found ways around this so that using the edge still
results in more performant uh requests by reducing request latencies so the example I want to use
for this is cloud flare smart placement and I I pulled this image off of their docs because it really illustrates the problem quite well but you have let's
say this user in Sydney Australia that makes a request and the edge location which in Cloud Flare's context um is a
cloud flare worker this is an edge function also in Sydney Australia picks up the request starts handling it and
now it has to make three requests to a database in Germany now to really highlight how how
long this request is taking the rule of thumb that I used to hear a number of years ago and I assume it still holds is
that anytime a request goes across the ocean it adds about 150 milliseconds round trip and users start to notice
sluggish at about 2 to 300 milliseconds so because there's three of them Happening Here the user going to notice
how slow this is now what cloudflare smart placement does is it pays attention to where the
outbound requests are going from The Edge function and it goes hm you know based on the fact that most
of the requests are going to this database in Germany it's actually more performant to move the edge function
closer to the database then it is to like it does by default run closer to
the user that made the original request so instead of something like this you get something like this where the edge
function is now running closer to that database in Germany and even though that initial request from the user in Sydney
Australia might take a little bit longer this still overall improves the performance of the request and gets
around that problem with the default behavior of the edge functionality running closest to the
user now this brings up a really interesting point that someone um one of the maintainers on the remakes framework
team and those those who might not be familiar with remakes it's a another popular JavaScript framework uh recently
and they made a great point that it doesn't matter how much of your application is running at the edge if
like in this example your data is still living in a distant a far away from the user and so the next Frontier for
boosting the performance of our applications isn't just figuring out how to get more application code on the edge
it's figuring out how to get data on the edge as well or at least make it accessible at the edge so we can cash
out and historically there's been a couple of challenges with doing so and they're your stereotypical database
problems the first is the limited number of connections that exist on a database how do you ensure that when tens of
thousands hundreds of thousands heck even millions of edge functions are spinning up and trying to access your
data that you don't exhaust the connections on your database your database goes down and it takes your application down with it the other
challenge is data consistency how do you ensure that when data is updated in one area of the world that the hash values
in other locations are invalidated and updated in a timely manner and there's a couple of different
approaches that different database vendors have taken to tackle this and the first one I want to talk about today is planet scales approach so you as a
user from an edge function you'll make your uh your database query normally and
what planet scale does is they have this Global routing infrastructure that they've characterized a similar to to a
CDN and so their Edge node essentially closest to your Edge function will pick
up that request and backhaul it over long held connection pools now there
might be a little bit of distance there but because this is happening with uh Planet scales internal Network this is a
faster request to fulfill than if you were just making this request over the public internet now to deal with the connection
pool problem Planet scale uses this open- Source uh database clustering software called vitess under the hood
which has its own connection pools and so as the database starts scaling to to
handle the um the amount of traffic coming in what'll happen is the Tess's connection pools will scale with it and
so it's able to handle this incredible amount of traffic without even breaking a sweat and to give an example of just
how much traffic they had a blog post where they talked about this loow testing and they were able to handle a million open connections no issues so
very ready for high-scale production grade traffic the other approach I want to
talk about today is cloud fl's durable objects so durable objects are to databases what serverless functions are
to web applications basically take this big monolithic thing and break it down into smaller
pieces when you create a durable object they're created in points of presence or
another fancy word for saying Edge location closest to the user that creates them they are globally unique
and they can only see and modify their own data which helps ensure the strong data consistency that we want to have from our dat our data storage
providers now the drawback to this approach is that if you as a developer require data from multiple durable
objects you'll need to make different requests to those different objects and Stitch that data together but with that
being said if you're using durable objects it's likely you're using other cloudfl services and so like in the
planet scale example those requests would be happening within Cloud flor's internal Network and will be faster to
make than if you were just making it over the public internet now you might be sitting there
and thinking but Erica I already have a database it's 5 10 20 30 years old I
have no appetite to switch to a different way of storing data is there anything that's available to me to make
my data accessible at the edge and start getting that performance boost and fortunately there is um the one that I
want to talk about or the thing I want to talk about today is cloud Flare's hyperdrive so how hyperdrive works is it
operates instances at the edge and it already improves performance because it maintains a warm connection with your
central database so it removes the latency that's incurred from that initial handshake now what I find really
cool about this tool is that it is able to distinguish between read and write queries and it caches the reads at the
edge so over time as requests come through those hyperdrive instances to query the database for data it starts to
make your central database feel like it's globally replicated along with the performance boost that that comes with
just having that data stored closer to users at the edge so a really nice option if if you're dealing with a more
Legacy system now I realized with the examples I've given so far that I might be giving
the false impression that the edge is just for web and full stack developers and that's really not the case the edge
is an incredibly flexible and uh very relevant tool for so many different
areas of software development and one group of developers that I think might want to take a closer look at the edge
for their Pro for their uh the problems that they're tackling are mobile developers because they have a couple of
technical challenges that are maybe a bit more top of mind for them than let's say web or full stack developers and the
first is the of intermittent connectivity we've likely all experienced a dead zone at some point in
our lives and with this in mind the speed at which requests are fulfilled is crucial to ensuring with a higher degree
of certainty that when the user does something on their device that they get a response
back the other challenge is that people don't update their apps um we likely all
know a friend or have a family member that never updates their OS in a timely manner or updates their apps and we as
an industry have gone a lot better about autom this process so that people don't even need to think about it but even
with that there are still some users that can't update their apps either for maybe reasons that they have like older
Hardware that they can't get rid of and going to a more a newer version results in their the support for their device
being dropped or they've run out of memory and they just they don't have room to update the
application so in order to account for this mobile developers are incentivized to deliver as much as possible from
servers that they control so that they can ship any security or critical fixes that they need to without relying on the
user to take action and building on that previous point on intermittent connectivity if this is if the server
that's being used to serve these requests is far away from the user it increases the odds that the request gets
dropped if that user enters the dead zone just and now it's not just a question of nice to have performance
it's a question of service reliability so by leveraging the edge in the mobile domain as we've seen even
just with our pet store example with the reduced request latencies and improves service reliability for those working in
the mobile space one approach that mobile developers can take a look at because this is an exist this is an
existing design pattern in this space is having an API layer at the edge and then caching popular responses there if uh in
the particular problem domain that you're working in you need like single digit latencies like near real-time
responsiveness I encourage you to take a look at Edge Computing that's offered through the 5G Network um this is
becoming more and more prevalent in major urban areas and the use case for this is like for self-driving cars so
very performant very reliable because obviously we don't want self-driving cars to just hit a dead zone and not work and then the other thing that you
you can look at if you're working in the mobile space is taken to to the extreme end here is looking at offline first or
um local first architectures where code and data is hosted on the device itself and it removes the Reliance on that
Central server now even with the challenges around connectivity I think we can
